messages.content: Hey there, awesome people!!! Can you believe this amazing weather?! I am absolutely THRILLED to share this sunny day and fun activities with all of you!!!! Let’s make this unforgettable!!! ????
"Good day, incredible humans!!!! The moment we’ve all been waiting for is finally here!!! I am beyond excited to embark on this journey with you – let the festivities begin!!!! ????????????"
"OMG!!! I just got the news and I HAVE to share it with you all!!! We hit our goal, team!!!! This is HUGE!!! I’m literally jumping with joy right now!!! ????????????"
"Guess what, guess what, GUESS WHAT?! Our favorite season is back, and I’m here for all the adventures!!! Can't wait to dive into the festivities with each and every one of you!!!! ????????????"
"Hi, hi, hi!!! Did everyone hear the fantastic update?! I am SOOOO excited to start this new chapter together!!! Cheers to new beginnings and epic journeys ahead!!! ????"
"YAY!!! It’s finally happening!!! Our big event is just around the corner, and I can’t contain my excitement!!!! Let’s rock this, team!!! ????????????"
"Hello, my wonderful friends!!!! I’ve got some absolutely thrilling news to share today!!! Hold onto your hats, because this is going to be a WILD ride!!! ????????????"
"Hey party people!!! Are you ready for the time of your lives?! Because I am bringing the energy and the fun – let’s make some magical memories together!!!! ????✨"
"WOW!!! Can we just take a moment?! I am overflowing with gratitude and excitement thanks to all of YOU!!! Let’s keep this amazing vibe going!!!! ❤️❤️❤️"
"Hellooooo bright and shining stars!!!! I’m buzzing with anticipation for what we’ve got planned! Are you as pumped as I am?! Let’s do this!!!! ????????????"

Writing “ex-Google” or “ex-Facebook” in your LinkedIn headline is like writing “my ex was hot and rich” on dating apps.

You’re more than your current or previous employers.

Please just let your experience section speak for itself.

Sincerely, 
Someone who’s tired of people putting Big Tech on a pedestal

P.S. Recruiter friends - what are your thoughts??

I increased my salary by 50% after being laid off from my last job. But the novelty of the new salary wore off within a month.

The story has been the same between every salary increase I’ve ever had:

1st job to 2nd job: 20% increase
2nd job to 3rd job: 25% increase
3rd job promotion: 10% increase
3rd job to 4th job: 50% increase

I’d be lying if I said the monetary benefits weren’t the primary motivation behind each jump. But the novelty of those benefits always wore off within a month or two.

Is it because I’m insatiable and greedy? No. It’s because after a certain point, the increase in salary is just a temporary ego stroke and not a real change to my lifestyle.

If you you would have told me this when I was a new grad—bright-eyed, bushy-tailed and believing that a 6-figure salary would make me worthier—I wouldn’t have believed you.

But now, after enough seasons of realizing work and the salary it provides—no matter how high—are just means to an end, I would tell you this:

It’s ok to celebrate having more money, because this capitalistic society tells us more money = more freedom.

But never ever believe more money = more personal value, because the excitement of more money will inevitably disappear, and along with it your sense of self worth.

In my past two roles in data startups, I was expected to be fully onboarded within 2 weeks of joining.

Imagine my surprise coming from the world of Big Corporate™, where I was literally told “We don’t expect you to be productive in your first 6 months in this job.”

The lightning-fast pace of working at early-stage startups is never something you really know how to prepare for until you’re thrown into the deep end.

And perhaps one of the deepest ends is when you’re first being onboarded at your new startup job, expected to drive value within your first month.

But the one tool I’ve used at both startups that has dramatically decreased the number of headaches in this process is a password manager like Nordpass.

Not only does it allow me to auto-fill my teams’ shared login credentials for the dozens of other tools I need access to,

But it also helps me organize my personal logins in one secure place while alerting me about data breaches as early as possible.

So if you’re in the startup world and need to secure and organize your team’s sensitive info for shared business accounts, or you’re just scatterbrained like me and always forget your logins

Check out Nordpass and use code “meganlieu” at 👉 nordpass.com/meganlieu for a free 3-month trial to start securely organizing your passwords today!

Calling all my data friends in finance: I’ve found the perfect learning event for you 🗣️

Tomorrow, 2/21 at 2 PM EST, join Ramdas Narayanan of Bank of America and David P. Mariani of AtScale as they chat about the role of data in financial services.

They’re chatting in depth about:

✅ Strategies for identifying market opportunities and strengthening customer relationships through data-driven insights
✅ The critical role of exceptional customer service in retaining customers and managing valuable customer
✅ The role of AI in personalization and scalable data infrastructure for AI-driven advertising campaigns
✅ Crafting intelligent product offerings and targeting customers effectively with precise data
✅ The importance of selecting the right markets for expansion, backed by robust data analysis

Register for this FREE learning event before spots run out 👉 https://bit.ly/3ucRE04

Thank you to AtScale for partnering with me to bring this free resource to my audience! 🙏

In 2024 we’re growing our library and our minds.

Currently on my nightstand: Data Engineering with AWS, by Gareth Eagar.

Keeping up with the tools and terminology in the world of the modern data stack can often feel like a never ending chase.

And I’m kind of ashamed to say I’ve fallen behind in the past few months, especially when it comes to data engineering concepts 🫣

Data lakehouses? Data meshes? Open table formats? And what do these all even mean in the context of the AWS ecosystem?

This book is Packt (get it?) with so much knowledge, and covers it all and so much more!

https://packt.link/PdsCz

Thank you to my friends at Packt for helping me get back on the upskilling train 🙏

You're probably not going to get a job from someone you know personally.

Now someone who knows someone you know? That's where the opportunities come from.

My current role at Deepnote came to me via a friend who was actually interviewing there at the same time (bless his heart), and below was the fateful message from my recruiter that changed everything for me.

These weak ties, a term coined by Mark Granovetter, are the casual acquaintances and loose connections that give you outside information that you otherwise would not have gotten in your own intimate sphere.

And how do you tap into your weak ties for your own job search?

1. 𝗗𝗼𝗻'𝘁 𝗯𝗲 𝘀𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁.
↳ I made one fateful post that brought plenty of new weak ties into my life, along with all of my interview opportunities.

2. 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝘂𝗽 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗰𝘁𝘀.
↳ Tools like Teal's Contact and Job Trackers allow you to stay organized and prevent opportunities from falling through the cracks.

3. 𝗞𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗮𝗻 𝘂𝗽𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆 𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲𝘀.
↳ Be prepared to tailor your resume to any opportunity that may come your way. Teal's AI Resume Builder helps you generate impactful bullet point achievements in seconds. 

Have you ever landed a job through your weak ties?

#sponsored #Tealpartner

Apply for the job even if you don’t meet all the qualifications…but don’t be delusional.

Be persistent and follow up because fortune favors the bold…but don’t be annoying and look desperate.

Don’t waste your time with cold applications…but if you do, make sure you’re tailoring every single application.

Let the world know you’re open to work…but don’t use the LinkedIn feature created to  let people know you’re open to work.

That’s why I’m such a fan of job search platforms that simplify the process instead of adding to the noise.

One such platform is Ramped, which offers everything you need to navigate your job search from beginning to end. Through a Ramped Premium membership, you get all this in one place:

✅ Job search and micro-credential courses
✅ Job application auto-filler Chrome extension

If you’re fed up with the whiplash, get access to Ramped Premium today so you can spend less time 𝘧𝘪𝘨𝘶𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘵𝘰 𝘥𝘰, and more time 𝘥𝘰𝘪𝘯𝘨.

Thank you to my friends at Ramped for partnering with me to spread the word about this platform!

100k on LinkedIn.

When I started writing on here a little over 2 years ago, I had 0 intention of growing a following, inspiring anyone, finding a community, or anything profound.

I did it because I wanted a job.

Somewhere between then and today, the mission changed to be one of “must reach 100k at all costs,” and boy did my mental health suffer because of it.

I can’t tell you how many times I’ve stared at a blank screen literally at midnight, begging for inspiration to hit because I “needed” to have my post ready to go as soon as I opened my eyes the next morning.

Growing up, I’ve often blindly chased goals that I thought I “needed” to accomplish at the expense of my own mental health, and the vanity goal of 100k followers has been no different.

What many don’t realize is how many moments of “I don’t want to do this anymore and no one is making me do it, but I’ll keep pushing anyway” go into creating content on LinkedIn.

I’d be doing a disservice to everyone who has supported me if I didn’t share that side of the journey - the writer’s block, the flopped posts, the hate from Reddit trolls, and the comparison game.

But for every low, there has been a high - making new friends, helping people land jobs or create their own content, reaching career milestones, and finding my voice.

And I would have never stumbled upon any of those highs if I hadn’t stuck it out through all the lows.

To the 100k people who have contributed to THIS high, thank you from the bottom of my heart.

Now time for a much needed break 🙏

"I would never work at a startup. I'm too risk-averse and I need structure in my life." 
 
- me, two early-stage startups ago 
 
When I took the leap from huge-corporation life to early-stage startup life, it went against everything I thought I needed for my work environments. 
 
But if I had let my fears get in the way, I know I definitely would not be where I am today. 
 
And today, after having worked at two big companies and two tiny companies, here's what I've found to be the difference: 
 
𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 
↳ At big companies you get to go deep in one niche area. At startups you develop a broader skillset by wearing multiple hats. 
 
𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 
↳ At big companies you have a pre-set, more frequent cadence for progression. At startups, promotions are less frequent, but can be big jumps when they do happen. 
 
𝗔𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗻𝗼𝗺𝘆 
↳ At big companies you get more structure but responsibilities are shared. At startups you have more autonomy but also more responsibility, which means more visibility. 
 
𝗕𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁𝘀 
↳ At big companies you receive more "traditional" benefits, e.g. cash, 401k, travel. At startups, the benefits are longer term and less "tangible", e.g. equity, team offsites. 
 
What I've learned from this comparison is that there will always be pros and cons to either side, but you'll never know them unless you give both a try. 
 
♻️ Repost for anyone considering making the switch between corporation and startup life!

4 things I wish I knew while I was sitting in my termination meeting, getting let go from my last job: 
 
1. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗸 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗲𝗿. 
 
The only words I could muster out amid the shock were “Thank you for the opportunity to work with you guys.” I wanted to say so many other things, but all I could think about then was not burning bridges. 
 
Now looking back, there were better ways to honor my true emotions and stick up for myself without needing to burn any bridges. 
 
2. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗹𝘆 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗽𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗽 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗻𝗲𝗴𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻. 
 
This was my biggest mistake. I signed on the dotted line the same day of my termination call because I “wanted to put this all behind me as soon as possible.” 
 
It wasn’t until after I signed, that a friend told me that my signature was basically me releasing my employer of all wrongdoing and giving up any possibility of negotiating for the severance I deserved. 
 
3. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗶𝗱𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝗮𝗰𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 - 𝗶𝗻 𝗳𝗮𝗰𝘁, 𝗽𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁. 
 
You’re going to feel shame and guilt in the moment. But you can either let those feelings keep you down, or you can own the fact that one door has closed and let the world know you’re ready for your next chapter. 
 
If I hadn’t made my fateful post, I would not have been able to get back on my feet as soon as I did, and I’m eternally grateful to my network for it. 
 
4. 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗿. 
 
My biggest regret was not giving myself more time to process my grief. In fact, I didn’t give myself the room to breathe or reflect on what happened until I started my next job. 
 
By then, I was thrown into the whirlwind of onboarding into a new role, and I missed my chance to give myself a much-needed break, mentally and emotionally. 
 
------------ 
 
No one prepares you for this “worst case scenario”, even though this scenario is happening to what feels like everyone these days. 
 
But perhaps the most important thing I learned was that this “worst case scenario” ended up being the best thing to happen to my career. 
 
♻️ Reshare for anyone who's been affected by job loss recently (or might be in the future 😬)

I used to be terrified of conferences.

The thought of a huge convention center packed with thousands of strangers you have to make small talk with is an absolute nightmare for anxious introverts like myself.

But this week, I’m at one of THE biggest data conferences, Gartner’s Data & Analytics Summit in Orlando, and I’m so dang excited to be here.

In fact, speaking at and attending conferences has easily become my favorite part of being a developer advocate. 

So what changed for me?

Realizing that conferences are just a way to make likeminded friends. A lot of them.

I’ve come away from every single conference with new connections that I otherwise could not have made had I only stayed in my little corner of LinkedIn.

And these connections have led to learnings, career opportunities and mentors within the data community that I could have never been exposed to had I let my comfort zone get in the way.

To any friends at Gartner this week, let me know if you’re here 👇 or come say hi if you see me (even if I’m recharging my introverted battery in a corner!)

---

P.S. I’ll be hanging out with SAP at booth 721 today, and I can’t wait to give you guys a behind-the-scenes look of this partnership!

Wanting a work-life balance doesn’t make you lazy. 
 
I’ve gone through periods of my career where my work life prevented me from living my *life* life. 
 
I’ve also gone through periods where I’ve had laser-focus on climbing the corporate ladder and put life on hold. 
 
And now, I’m at the point where I just want my 9-5 and my 5-9 to live in perfect harmony. 
 
This economy and my past lives as a workaholic would label that as “being lazy.” 
 
In reality, craving a balance that allows you to thrive in all aspects of life is not laziness, it’s honoring yourself and your boundaries.

♻️ Reshare for someone figuring out their work-life balance in your life!

When I first started writing on LinkedIn, there were a few creators I looked up to that started it all for me. 

And this past weekend, I got to meet all of them.

it’s hard to put into words how valuable a support system is in the data content creation space, because so few people GET IT.

Writers’ block
Impostor syndrome
Monetizing platforms
Balancing it with our jobs
Burnout from all of the above

I’ve been dealing with all of these things and questioning my purpose here on LinkedIn a lot lately. 

And it wasn’t until this weekend that I finally felt SEEN. Like I didn’t have to deal with these struggles alone.

Extremely humbled to be able to call these role models my friends now 🙏

P.S. How many of your favorite data creators can you spot??

The amazing and scary thing about LinkedIn is that you can convince people you have skills that you actually don’t.

During my last job search, I sat for plenty of interviews I was completely unqualified for. All because I had the title “Data Scientist” and a decent following on LinkedIn.

During the time I had that title, I was little more than a product/data analyst, if I had to be completely honest with you 😬

Was I flattered that recruiters were reaching out to me for machine learning engineer and AI strategist roles when I didn’t do anything close to the skills required for them? Yes.

Was I stuck in an awkward situation when the recruiters asked me about my experience with those skills and it was pretty obvious I was bullshi*ting them? Yes.

During my fourth call like this, I remember thinking to myself, “Wow they REALLY think I’m this hardcore data scientist just because I have this fake title and lots of followers. This is funny but actually kinda scary 😳”

And sure, this sounds like a first-world problem, because I really truly do empathize with the thousands of job seekers out there right now who can’t even land interviews for the roles they ARE qualified for.

But I learned from getting so many of these calls, that it is so much better to not get an interview for a role you may have been qualified for than to get one for a role that was such a wrong fit that it just makes your imposter syndrome 10x worse.

So my takeaways are two fold:

Job seekers - LinkedIn can open doors for you that you never imagined possible, but your titles and headlines can only get you so far.

Recruiters and hiring managers - Titles + follower count ≠ expertise.

Imagine a world where Generative AI can be used in every corner of a business, wherever there’s data.

In the past, this was limited by contextless, messy, disconnected data from a company’s dozens, if not hundreds, of different data sources. But today, that world is a reality.

During the SAP Data Unleashed event, SAP announced some pretty game-changing innovations to SAP Datasphere, which powers business data fabric architectures so that companies can enable real-time data connectivity across its systems.

These innovations include SAP Datasphere knowledge graph, its integration with SAP Analytics Cloud, and an expanded ecosystem through partnerships with companies like Collibra and Confluent.

All of these announcements mean it’s easier than ever for companies to simplify their data landscapes while preserving the data’s business context through the data fabric architecture. But the Generative AI cherry on top is Joule Copilot 👌

SAP Joule allows anyone to ask even the most open-ended questions of their data while having transparency into *how* Generative AI was used to answer the question thanks to the Datasphere knowledge graph.

AI implemented across an organization is worthless if it’s not *trusted* AI, and this was the crucial takeaway from SAP Data Unleashed.

If you missed the event, you can find a great recap in this blog post 👉 https://lnkd.in/eW9-S9Vt

I’m excited for the possibilities of this future where trusted AI, and the trusted data that powers it, becomes fully integrated into every facet of a business.

Thank you SAP for partnering with me and giving me a glimpse into this future so that I can share it with my audience! 🙏

3 lessons learned from 28 years around the sun:

1. 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀
↳ I increased my salary significantly this year, but practically nothing’s changed. I still drive my beat up 2010 silver Toyota Camry and save as much as I can.

2. 𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘁𝗵 𝗶𝘀 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗮𝘀 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝘀 𝗽𝗵𝘆𝘀𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹
↳ For over a decade, I had let obsessive exercise and nutrition habits consume me. This year, I finally let them go, and my mental health thanked me for it.

3. 𝗔𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗮 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝘄𝗲𝗮𝗸𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀
↳ I was back on my feet after a month of being jobless because I had the courage to be vulnerable and ask for help. Best decision I made all year.

27 was the year I was able to be super open on LinkedIn about my struggles and these lessons learned. And to my surprise, I received so much love along the way.

So 28, if you’re even just a fraction as rewarding as 27 was, I’m so ready.

Thank you to every single person who’s taken the time to read my silly little LinkedIn posts this year. To be able to put my thoughts down in writing and have people actually care about what I have to say is a privilege I’ll never take for granted ❤️

My Roman Empire is how data is literally everywhere and powers everything we do, but we can’t see it or feel it 🤯

From the online orders that arrive at your door, to digital signs on the highway, to the posts shown on your social media feeds.

Every now and then while mindlessly consuming data from every facet of my life, I stop to think about all the data people and technologies that make these things possible.

How do the 0s and 1s get transformed into anything of value? How does it happen so fast? More importantly, how does it all stay organized??

These are the thoughts that keep a data nerd up at night 😵‍💫

A term that I recently learned that answers all of those questions is a ✨business data fabric✨

This is a modern data architecture that allows companies to centralize their data across their different systems and access it in real-time wherever it’s deployed, all while preserving the business context of the data from start to finish. 

Now imagine the accessibility advantages this kind of architecture brings to AI and machine learning use cases. The data nerd in me gets excited just thinking about the possibilities!

As business data fabrics start gaining more traction, I’m making sure I’m keeping up by finding resources published by the leading players in the space.

SAP is one of those leaders, especially with their release of SAP Datasphere last year, and they’re hosting a FREE virtual event tomorrow, March 6 (my birthday!) at 11 am EST to talk all about business data fabrics, their real-world use cases, and how it powers GenAI capabilities.

Join me at SAP Data Unleashed on my birthday by registering today at 👉 bit.ly/Megansbday 🎂

#SAPDataUnleashed #sponsored

I’ve been PIP’ed and fired before.

And when these things happened, I told myself I’d share the story in 10-20 years, when I’m way more established and these mistakes will hopefully seem trivial in comparison to all the career successes I’ll have.

Well it’s only been <5 years in my adult career, and I’m already openly admitting that I’ve held jobs where I wasn’t proud of my work, and I paid the consequences for it.

Because also in those <5 years, I’ve also held jobs where I’ve felt motivated, valued, and challenged to give my all.

And the latter would have never happened had I not hit rock bottom. Multiple times.

But I’m also admitting these failures because in the moments when they happened, I carried so much shame because my jobs WERE my identity.

Failing at my job meant 𝘐 was a failure.

In a day and age when layoffs are happening left and right, you hear plenty of job loss stories from people who were impacted by no fault of their own.

So why do I want to add my alternative job loss story—one where no one was to blame but myself—to the narrative?

Because I’m tired of feeling that shame. Shame for something that happens to more people than you think.

I turn 28 in 2 days. I think now is the age I finally realize that it’s unrealistic to think everyone around you is always successful, hard working and growing in everything they do at all times!

And if you’re not “on” 24/7 like you think everyone else is, then you’re a failure. This comparison fallacy alone has contributed to 99% of the shame I refuse to feel anymore.

Let’s stop with this limited narrative about what career successes and even failures look like. 

And start being more gracious toward ourselves for making mistakes, needing breaks and growing in directions different than planned. 

Those things all make us human.

♻️ Repost if you are human!

You know what’s better than job security? ‘Me’ security.

Aka the confidence that even if you find yourself without a job one day, you have the skills and assets to end up back on your feet quickly.

When I was let go from my last job, I was unemployed for just 4 weeks because I had invested in my ‘me’ security consistently for years before I needed a job:

𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝘁 𝘂𝗽 𝗺𝘆 𝗻𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝘁 𝗯𝗲𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽
↳ Before I made one fateful post announcing I was back on the job market, I had spent years networking and contributing to the data community. Give before you take.

𝗞𝗲𝗽𝘁 𝗺𝘆 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝘀𝗲𝗲𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗽
↳ Job seeking is a skill in and of itself. The tool that helped me keep this skill sharp was good old LinkedIn, and not just using it when I was in desperate need for a job.

𝗦𝗮𝘃𝗲𝗱 𝘂𝗽 𝗮𝘁 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝟲 𝗺𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗵𝘀’ 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗵 𝗼𝗳 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀𝗲𝘀
↳ This doesn’t help you land a job directly, but instead gives you the peace of mind to know you can keep going in the search despite any setbacks.

𝗞𝗲𝗽𝘁 𝗺𝘆 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘂𝗽 𝘁𝗼 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲
↳ Self-explanatory, but so hard to do in practice because dusting off the resume cobwebs when you don’t actively need a new job can often feel like pulling teeth.
